content: David is committed to helping communities and organizations decarbonize and meet their sustainability goals. His focus is on scaling energy efficiency, renewable energy, and sustainable transportation. He utilizes skills in data analysis, research, collaboration, and project management to find and implement solutions. David is currently specializing in energy and climate at the Bren School of Environmental Science and Management to gain a better understanding of the science behind global warming and the practical solutions at our disposal.
summary: David is committed to helping communities and organizations decarbonize and meet their sustainability goals. His focus is on scaling energy efficiency, renewable energy, and sustainable transportation. He utilizes skills in data analysis, research, collaboration, and project management to find and implement solutions. David is currently specializing in energy and climate at the Bren School of Environmental Science and Management to gain a better understanding of the science behind global warming and the practical solutions at our disposal.
title: David Segan

content:
Flexibility This feature can be used for publishing content such as:
 Online courses Project or software documentation Tutorials  The courses folder may be renamed. For example, we can rename it to docs for software/project documentation or tutorials for creating an online course.
Delete tutorials To remove these pages, delete the courses folder and see below to delete the associated menu link.
Update site menu After renaming or deleting the courses folder, you may wish to update any [[main]] menu links to it by editing your menu configuration at config/_default/menus.toml.
For example, if you delete this folder, you can remove the following from your menu configuration:
[[main]] name = "Courses" url = "courses/" weight = 50  Or, if you are creating a software documentation site, you can rename the courses folder to docs and update the associated Courses menu configuration to:
[[main]] name = "Docs" url = "docs/" weight = 50  Update the docs menu If you use the docs layout, note that the name of the menu in the front matter should be in the form [menu.X] where X is the folder name. Hence, if you rename the courses/example/ folder, you should also rename the menu definitions in the front matter of files within courses/example/ from [menu.example] to [menu.<NewFolderName>].
summary: Learn how to use Academic's docs layout for publishing online courses, software documentation, and tutorials.
title: Overview

title: Example Page 2

content:
Click on the Slides button above to view the built-in slides feature.   Slides can be added in a few ways:
 Create slides using Academic’s Slides feature and link using slides parameter in the front matter of the talk file Upload an existing slide deck to static/ and link using url_slides parameter in the front matter of the talk file Embed your slides (e.g. Google Slides) or presentation video on this page using shortcodes.  Further talk details can easily be added to this page using Markdown and $\rm \LaTeX$ math code.
summary: An example talk using Academic's Markdown slides feature.
title: Example Talk

content:
Academic is designed to give technical content creators a seamless experience. You can focus on the content and Academic handles the rest.
Highlight your code snippets, take notes on math classes, and draw diagrams from textual representation.
On this page, you’ll find some examples of the types of technical content that can be rendered with Academic.
Examples Code Academic supports a Markdown extension for highlighting code syntax. You can enable this feature by toggling the highlight option in your config/_default/params.toml file.
```python import pandas as pd data = pd.read_csv("data.csv") data.head() ```  renders as
import pandas as pd data = pd.read_csv("data.csv") data.head()  Math Academic supports a Markdown extension for $\LaTeX$ math. You can enable this feature by toggling the math option in your config/_default/params.toml file.
To render inline or block math, wrap your LaTeX math with $...$ or $$...$$, respectively.
Example math block:
$$\gamma_{n} = \frac{ \left | \left (\mathbf x_{n} - \mathbf x_{n-1} \right )^T \left [\nabla F (\mathbf x_{n}) - \nabla F (\mathbf x_{n-1}) \right ] \right |} {\left \|\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n}) - \nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n-1}) \right \|^2}$$  renders as
$$\gamma_{n} = \frac{ \left | \left (\mathbf x_{n} - \mathbf x_{n-1} \right )^T \left [\nabla F (\mathbf x_{n}) - \nabla F (\mathbf x_{n-1}) \right ] \right |}{\left |\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n}) - \nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n-1}) \right |^2}$$
Example inline math $\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n})$ renders as $\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n})$.
Example multi-line math using the \\ math linebreak:
$$f(k;p_0^*) = \begin{cases} p_0^* & \text{if }k=1, \\ 1-p_0^* & \text {if }k=0.\end{cases}$$  renders as
$$f(k;p_0^*) = \begin{cases} p_0^* & \text{if }k=1, \
1-p_0^* & \text {if }k=0.\end{cases}$$
Diagrams Academic supports a Markdown extension for diagrams. You can enable this feature by toggling the diagram option in your config/_default/params.toml file or by adding diagram: true to your page front matter.
An example flowchart:
```mermaid graph TD A[Hard] -->|Text| B(Round) B --> C{Decision} C -->|One| D[Result 1] C -->|Two| E[Result 2] ```  renders as
graph TD A[Hard] -->|Text| B(Round) B --> C{Decision} C -->|One| D[Result 1] C -->|Two| E[Result 2]  An example sequence diagram:
```mermaid sequenceDiagram Alice->>John: Hello John, how are you? loop Healthcheck John->>John: Fight against hypochondria end Note right of John: Rational thoughts! John-->>Alice: Great! John->>Bob: How about you? Bob-->>John: Jolly good! ```  renders as
sequenceDiagram Alice->>John: Hello John, how are you? loop Healthcheck John->>John: Fight against hypochondria end Note right of John: Rational thoughts! John-->>Alice: Great! John->>Bob: How about you? Bob-->>John: Jolly good!  An example Gantt diagram:
```mermaid gantt section Section Completed :done, des1, 2014-01-06,2014-01-08 Active :active, des2, 2014-01-07, 3d Parallel 1 : des3, after des1, 1d Parallel 2 : des4, after des1, 1d Parallel 3 : des5, after des3, 1d Parallel 4 : des6, after des4, 1d ```  renders as
gantt section Section Completed :done, des1, 2014-01-06,2014-01-08 Active :active, des2, 2014-01-07, 3d Parallel 1 : des3, after des1, 1d Parallel 2 : des4, after des1, 1d Parallel 3 : des5, after des3, 1d Parallel 4 : des6, after des4, 1d  An example class diagram:
```mermaid classDiagram Class01 <|-- AveryLongClass : Cool <<interface>> Class01 Class09 --> C2 : Where am i? Class09 --* C3 Class09 --|> Class07 Class07 : equals() Class07 : Object[] elementData Class01 : size() Class01 : int chimp Class01 : int gorilla class Class10 { <<service>> int id size() } ```  renders as
classDiagram Class01 <|-- AveryLongClass : Cool <<interface>> Class01 Class09 --> C2 : Where am i? Class09 --* C3 Class09 --|> Class07 Class07 : equals() Class07 : Object[] elementData Class01 : size() Class01 : int chimp Class01 : int gorilla class Class10 { <<service>> int id size() }  An example state diagram:
```mermaid stateDiagram [*] --> Still Still --> [*] Still --> Moving Moving --> Still Moving --> Crash Crash --> [*] ```  renders as
stateDiagram [*] --> Still Still --> [*] Still --> Moving Moving --> Still Moving --> Crash Crash --> [*]  Todo lists You can even write your todo lists in Academic too:
- [x] Write math example - [x] Write diagram example - [ ] Do something else  renders as
 Write math example Write diagram example Do something else  Tables Represent your data in tables:
| First Header | Second Header | | ------------- | ------------- | | Content Cell | Content Cell | | Content Cell | Content Cell |  renders as
   First Header Second Header     Content Cell Content Cell   Content Cell Content Cell    Asides Academic supports a shortcode for asides, also referred to as notices, hints, or alerts. By wrapping a paragraph in {{% alert note %}} ... {{% /alert %}}, it will render as an aside.
{{% alert note %}} A Markdown aside is useful for displaying notices, hints, or definitions to your readers. {{% /alert %}}  renders as
 A Markdown aside is useful for displaying notices, hints, or definitions to your readers.   Icons Academic enables you to use a wide range of icons from Font Awesome and Academicons in addition to emojis.
Here are some examples using the icon shortcode to render icons:
{{< icon name="terminal" pack="fas" >}} Terminal {{< icon name="python" pack="fab" >}} Python {{< icon name="r-project" pack="fab" >}} R  renders as
  Terminal
 Python
 R
Did you find this page helpful? Consider sharing it 🙌
summary:
Academic is designed to give technical content creators a seamless experience. You can focus on the content and Academic handles the rest.
Highlight your code snippets, take notes on math classes, and draw diagrams from textual representation.
On this page, you’ll find some examples of the types of technical content that can be rendered with Academic.
Examples Code Academic supports a Markdown extension for highlighting code syntax. You can enable this feature by toggling the highlight option in your config/_default/params.
title: Writing technical content in Academic

content: Click the Slides button above to demo Academic’s Markdown slides feature.   Supplementary notes can be added here, including code and math.
summary: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Duis posuere tellus ac convallis placerat. Proin tincidunt magna sed ex sollicitudin condimentum.
title: An example preprint / working paper

content:
from IPython.core.display import Image Image('https://www.python.org/static/community_logos/python-logo-master-v3-TM-flattened.png')  print("Welcome to Academic!")  Welcome to Academic!  Install Python and JupyterLab  Install Anaconda which includes Python 3 and JupyterLab.
Alternatively, install JupyterLab with pip3 install jupyterlab.
Create or upload a Jupyter notebook Run the following commands in your Terminal, substituting <MY-WEBSITE-FOLDER> and <SHORT-POST-TITLE> with the file path to your Academic website folder and a short title for your blog post (use hyphens instead of spaces), respectively:
mkdir -p <MY-WEBSITE-FOLDER>/content/post/<SHORT-POST-TITLE>/ cd <MY-WEBSITE-FOLDER>/content/post/<SHORT-POST-TITLE>/ jupyter lab index.ipynb  The jupyter command above will launch the JupyterLab editor, allowing us to add Academic metadata and write the content.
Edit your post metadata The first cell of your Jupter notebook will contain your post metadata ( front matter).
In Jupter, choose Markdown as the type of the first cell and wrap your Academic metadata in three dashes, indicating that it is YAML front matter:
--- title: My post's title date: 2019-09-01 # Put any other Academic metadata here... ---  Edit the metadata of your post, using the documentation as a guide to the available options.
To set a featured image, place an image named featured into your post’s folder.
For other tips, such as using math, see the guide on writing content with Academic.
Convert notebook to Markdown jupyter nbconvert index.ipynb --to markdown --NbConvertApp.output_files_dir=.  Example This post was created with Jupyter. The orginal files can be found at https://github.com/gcushen/hugo-academic/tree/master/exampleSite/content/post/jupyter
summary: Learn how to blog in Academic using Jupyter notebooks
title: Display Jupyter Notebooks with Academic

content:
Create slides in Markdown with Academic  Academic | Documentation
 Features  Efficiently write slides in Markdown 3-in-1: Create, Present, and Publish your slides Supports speaker notes Mobile friendly slides   Controls  Next: Right Arrow or Space Previous: Left Arrow Start: Home Finish: End Overview: Esc Speaker notes: S Fullscreen: F Zoom: Alt + Click  PDF Export: E   Code Highlighting Inline code: variable
Code block:
porridge = "blueberry" if porridge == "blueberry": print("Eating...")   Math In-line math: $x + y = z$
Block math:
$$ f\left( x \right) = ;\frac{{2\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x - 4} \right)}}{{\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x + 1} \right)}} $$
 Fragments Make content appear incrementally
{{% fragment %}} One {{% /fragment %}} {{% fragment %}} **Two** {{% /fragment %}} {{% fragment %}} Three {{% /fragment %}}  Press Space to play!
One  Two  Three 
 A fragment can accept two optional parameters:
 class: use a custom style (requires definition in custom CSS) weight: sets the order in which a fragment appears   Speaker Notes Add speaker notes to your presentation
{{% speaker_note %}} - Only the speaker can read these notes - Press `S` key to view {{% /speaker_note %}}  Press the S key to view the speaker notes!
 Only the speaker can read these notes Press S key to view    Themes  black: Black background, white text, blue links (default) white: White background, black text, blue links league: Gray background, white text, blue links beige: Beige background, dark text, brown links sky: Blue background, thin dark text, blue links    night: Black background, thick white text, orange links serif: Cappuccino background, gray text, brown links simple: White background, black text, blue links solarized: Cream-colored background, dark green text, blue links   Custom Slide Customize the slide style and background
{{< slide background-image="/img/boards.jpg" >}} {{< slide background-color="#0000FF" >}} {{< slide class="my-style" >}}   Custom CSS Example Let’s make headers navy colored.
Create assets/css/reveal_custom.css with:
.reveal section h1, .reveal section h2, .reveal section h3 { color: navy; }   Questions?  Ask
 Documentation
summary: An introduction to using Academic's Slides feature.
title: Slides

content:
Create a free website with Academic using Markdown, Jupyter, or RStudio. Choose a beautiful color theme and build anything with the Page Builder - over 40 widgets, themes, and language packs included!
 Check out the latest demo of what you’ll get in less than 10 minutes, or view the showcase of personal, project, and business sites.
 👉 Get Started 📚 View the documentation 💬 Ask a question on the forum 👥 Chat with the community 🐦 Twitter: @source_themes @GeorgeCushen #MadeWithAcademic 💡 Request a feature or report a bug ⬆️ Updating? View the Update Guide and Release Notes ❤ Support development of Academic:  ☕️ Donate a coffee 💵 Become a backer on Patreon 🖼️ Decorate your laptop or journal with an Academic sticker 👕 Wear the T-shirt 👩‍💻 Contribute       Academic is mobile first with a responsive design to ensure that your site looks stunning on every device.   Key features:
 Page builder - Create anything with widgets and elements Edit any type of content - Blog posts, publications, talks, slides, projects, and more! Create content in Markdown, Jupyter, or RStudio Plugin System - Fully customizable color and font themes Display Code and Math - Code highlighting and LaTeX math supported Integrations - Google Analytics, Disqus commenting, Maps, Contact Forms, and more! Beautiful Site - Simple and refreshing one page design Industry-Leading SEO - Help get your website found on search engines and social media Media Galleries - Display your images and videos with captions in a customizable gallery Mobile Friendly - Look amazing on every screen with a mobile friendly version of your site Multi-language - 15+ language packs including English, 中文, and Português Multi-user - Each author gets their own profile page Privacy Pack - Assists with GDPR Stand Out - Bring your site to life with animation, parallax backgrounds, and scroll effects One-Click Deployment - No servers. No databases. Only files.  Themes Academic comes with automatic day (light) and night (dark) mode built-in. Alternatively, visitors can choose their preferred mode - click the sun/moon icon in the top right of the Demo to see it in action! Day/night mode can also be disabled by the site admin in params.toml.
 Choose a stunning theme and font for your site. Themes are fully customizable.
Ecosystem   Academic Admin: An admin tool to import publications from BibTeX or import assets for an offline site  Academic Scripts: Scripts to help migrate content to new versions of Academic  Install You can choose from one of the following four methods to install:
  one-click install using your web browser (recommended)  install on your computer using Git with the Command Prompt/Terminal app  install on your computer by downloading the ZIP files  install on your computer with RStudio  Then personalize and deploy your new site.
Updating  View the Update Guide.
Feel free to star the project on Github to help keep track of updates.
License Copyright 2016-present George Cushen.
Released under the MIT license.
summary: Create a beautifully simple website in under 10 minutes.
title: Academic: the website builder for Hugo

content:
R Markdown This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com.
You can embed an R code chunk like this:
summary(cars) ## speed dist ## Min. : 4.0 Min. : 2.00 ## 1st Qu.:12.0 1st Qu.: 26.00 ## Median :15.0 Median : 36.00 ## Mean :15.4 Mean : 42.98 ## 3rd Qu.:19.0 3rd Qu.: 56.00 ## Max. :25.0 Max. :120.00 fit <- lm(dist ~ speed, data = cars) fit ## ## Call: ## lm(formula = dist ~ speed, data = cars) ## ## Coefficients: ## (Intercept) speed ## -17.579 3.932  Including Plots You can also embed plots. See Figure 1 for example:
par(mar = c(0, 1, 0, 1)) pie( c(280, 60, 20), c('Sky', 'Sunny side of pyramid', 'Shady side of pyramid'), col = c('#0292D8', '#F7EA39', '#C4B632'), init.angle = -50, border = NA )  Figure 1: A fancy pie chart.

summary(cars) ## speed dist ## Min. : 4.0 Min. : 2.00 ## 1st Qu.:12.0 1st Qu.: 26.00 ## Median :15.0 Median : 36.00 ## Mean :15.4 Mean : 42.98 ## 3rd Qu.

content:
Introduction Nestled alongside Oregon’s McKenzie River lies Mack Creek, a forest-dense aquatic area that provides habitat for the Pacific Giant Salamander. The density of forest alongside Mack Creek varies greatly between different forest sections due to historic forest clear-cutting. It is not fully understood whether the clear-cutting of forest has had a significant impact on the Pacific Giant Salamander population in Mack Creek. Fortunately, for the purposes of this report, the Pacific Giant Salamander population along Mack Creek has been monitored in both a clear-cut forest section and a 500-year-old, old-growth forest section since 1993 (Gregory S. V. 2016). Data from this monitoring of Pacific Giant Salamanders includes the specific location of individual observations, overall counts, and individual weights (Gregory S. V. 2016). Here, we analyze this data to provide insight into the the effect that forest clear-cutting has on Pacific Giant Salamander populations in Mack Creek.
Mack Creek Location. Dana Warren.
 Pacific Giant Salamander. Photo by Karl H. Switak
  Data and Methods Annually collected data on the Pacific giant salamanders from 1993 to 2017 in the old growth section and the previously clear-cut section of the Andrews Experimental Forest was used for the analysis. Among these two groups, counts, weights, and location of salamanders within the Mack Creek channel (pool, cascade, or side-channel) were analyzed using a significance level of 0.05. For more information on collection methods and variables, see metadata. A chi-squared test was used to determine if there is a significant effect of forest condition (old growth vs clear cut) on where in the channel Pacific Giant Salamander’s are found (Cascades, Side-Channel, and Pool). A two-sample t-test was used to compare the weights of Pacific Giant Salamanders between the two forest sections. Lastly, a one-way ANOVA test, along with Tukey’s HSD and Cohen’s D for post-hoc testing was conducted to compare mean weights across channel locations.
 Results Part A: Visual Comparison of Salamander Counts Figure 1: Counts of Pacific Giant Salamander’s compared between clear-cut forest section and old-growth forest section between 1993 and 2017.
Trends in Giant Pacific Salamander counts were compared between clear-cut and old-growth forest sections between 1993 and 2017 (Figure 1). Noticeably, there is little visual difference in the fluctuation of salamander counts in old-growth and clear-cut forest sections. Despite little difference in the fluctuation of salamander counts, on average, salamander counts in old-growth forest sections were greater until 2014. Populations of Giant Pacific Salamanders in both the clear-cut and old-growth forest sections experienced significant decline in populations between 2013 and 2015.
 Results B: 2017 Salamander Counts by Channel Classification Table 1: 2017 Salamander counts by channel classification (pool, cascades, and side-channel) in old-growth and clear-cut sections of Mack Creek. Proportions provide insight into the relationship that exists between forest section and the channel section where Pacific Giant Salamanders were observed.   Section  Cascades  Pool  Side Channel      Clear Cut  247 (67.1%)  31 (8.4%)  90 (24.5%)    Old Growth  201 (62.8%)  45 (14.1%)  74 (23.1%)      Results C: Analysis of Salamander Counts by Channel Classification A chi-squared test of independence was conducted to analyze whether there is a significant effect of forest condition on the channel classification where Pacific Giant Salamanders were observed. The analysis shows that, at a 95% confidence level, there is not a significant effect of forest section on where Pacific Giant Salamanders were observed (p-value: 0.0626). Despite unequal distribution of salamander counts across forest sections (as seen in Table 1), there is not a statistically significant relationship that exists between forest section and channel classification at the 95% confidence level.
 Results D: Pacific Giant Salamander Weights by Section Figure 2: Comparison of weights of Pacific Giant Salamanders observed in clear-cut forest section and old-growth forest section. Mean weight is displayed as black dot with error bars that display one standard deviation from mean. Mean weight of Pacific Giant Salamanders in clear-cut forest sections = 7.78g, and old-growth forest section = 6.58g.
A Welch’s two sample t-test was conducted to analyze whether there is a significant difference in mean weight of Pacific Giant Salamanders in clear-cut and old-growth forest sections. Test results show that, at a 95% confidence level, there is not a significant difference in the mean weight of Pacific Giant Salamanders between the two forest sections (p-value: 0.096). These results reinforce findings in Results A, Results B, and Results C, that indicate that there is no significant effect of forest section on Pacific Giant Salamander populations in Mack Creek.
 Results E: Means Comparison of Salamander Weight by Channel Classification Figure 3: Comparison of weights of Pacific Giant Salamanders observed in Cascades, Pools, or Side Channels.
 Figure 4: QQ plot to explore normalcy of data spread for weights of Pacific Giant Salamanders observed in different channel classifications (Cascades, Pool, Side-Channel). Actual values of observations were plotted with theoretical normal values and yielded slightly abnormal results.
 Levene’s Test for Equal Variance  Levene’s Test Result: With a p-value of 0.093, this is not significant and we retain the null hypothesis of equal variances.   One-way ANOVA & Post-Hoc Testing:  ANOVA Result: Mean salamander weight (g) differed significantly between the three channel classifications (pool, cascade, side-channel) based on a one-way ANOVA test (F(2, 684) = 4.22, p-value = 0.015). Tukey’s HSD Result: Pairwise testing reveals that mean weights of Pool salamanders differ significantly from Side Channel salamanders (p-value = 0.017), however, means of other pairwise combinations do not differ significantly. Pool salamanders and Cascade salamanders: (p-value = 0.286). Side channel salamanders and Cascade salamanders: (p-value = 0.084) Effect size: Even though a significant difference in means is found between salamanders sampled in pools vs. side-channels, the effect size is small as tested with Cohen’s d: (d estimate = 0.35)   Analysis of Results  An Anova test was conducted to compare mean weights of salamanders across channel classifications, regardless of forest section. The results show that at the 95% confidence level, mean salamander weight was only significantly different between salamanders in side channels vs those in pools. While significantly different, the effect size is small, thus leading a conclusion that there is not considerable difference in Pacific Giant Salamander weight across channel classifications. Prior to conducting the ANOVA, a QQ plot was created to evaluate normalcy of the weight distributions. The QQ plot revealed that the distributions of weights within each channel type is slightly abnormal. While this raises slight concern for the effectiveness of an ANOVA, it is widely accepted that an ANOVA is robust to violation of the normality assumption. Coupled with a Levene’s test that indicates non-significant difference in variance, the results of the ANOVA test are still valuable. Median weights should be compared for further analysis.    Summary  Pacific Giant Salamander counts have fluctuated greatly in Mack Creek from 1993 to 2018. These fluctuations have largely been the same in the previously clear cut section of the forest as in the old growth section of forest (Figure 1). In 2017, mean weight of Pacfic Giant Salamanders sampled in clear-cut forests were 1.2 grams larger (~18% larger) than those sampled in old growth forest sections.(Figure 2) Despite differences in actual data, statistical tests show inconclusive evidence that any strong relationships exist at the 95% confidence level between 1) forest section and where the Pacific Giant Salamander are found, 2) weights of the salamanders across forest sections, and 3) weights of the salamanders across channel classifications. (Results B, C, D, & E)   References Gregory S. V. 2016. Aquatic Vertebrate Population Study in Mack Creek, Andrews Experimental Forest, 1987 to present. Environmental Data Initiative. https://doi.org/10.6073/pasta/5de64af9c11579266ef20da2ff32f702. Dataset accessed 12/01/2019

The density of forest alongside Mack Creek varies greatly between different forest sections due to historic forest clear-cutting. title: Analysis of Pacific Giant Salamanders in Mack Creek, OR

summary: Introduction In 2012, the California Fish and Game Network of Marine Protected Areas (MPA) established two MPAs along the Santa Barbara coastline, one in Isla Vista and another in Naples (Reed 2019). Like much of the Santa Barbara coastline, Isla Vista and Naples are home to the spiny lobster. The spiny lobster serves as an important predator in kelp forests off the California coastline (Reed 2019).
title: Effect of Marine Protected Area Designation on Spiny Lobster Populations

content:
Visualization of Mono Lake water levels over time and the effect of diversions to meet the water demands of Los Angeles.
Data sources: 1850-1912 from Stine, Scott (based on occasional observations and San Francisco precipitation). 1912-1979 from LADWP and USGS compilations. 1979-present from Los Angeles Aqueduct Daily Reports, and observations by the Mono Lake Committee. Compiled by the Mono Lake Committee.
summary:
Visualization of Mono Lake water levels over time and the effect of diversions to meet the water demands of Los Angeles.
Data sources: 1850-1912 from Stine, Scott (based on occasional observations and San Francisco precipitation). 1912-1979 from LADWP and USGS compilations. 1979-present from Los Angeles Aqueduct Daily Reports, and observations by the Mono Lake Committee. Compiled by the Mono Lake Committee.
title: Mono Lake Water Levels

content:
Introduction This analysis looks at Steelhead salmon passage across the Bonneville Dam in Oregon from 1940 - 2019. The primary data collection is done byt the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers. The data includes counts of Steelhead Salmon recorded daily. There were days that did not include any salmon recordings and these data were removed from the analysis. Included in this analysis are a graph of daily recordings, a comparison of how seasonal recordings have changed over the years, and a graph of annual counts.
Reference: Columbia River DART, Columbia Basin Research, University of Washington. (2019). Adult Passage Graphics & Text. Available from http://www.cbr.washington.edu/dart/query/adult_graph_text
Bonneville Dam spillway. Photo curtesy of the Bonneville Dam Wikipedia page, visitor7.
  Visualing exploring the data # ----------------- # Install libraries # ------------------ library(tidyverse) library(janitor) library(here) library(lubridate) library(paletteer) library(tsibble) # ---------------- # Read in csv # --------------- steelhead <- read_csv("cbr_fish_passage_bonneville_allyrs_steelhead.csv") %>% clean_names() # Note on data classes: year is number & mm_dd is character # Also mm_dd is mislabeled, it is actually dd_mm # --------------- # Correct dates # --------------- steelhead_dates <- steelhead %>% # combine date columns using str_c mutate(yr_day_mo = str_c(year, mm_dd, sep = "-")) %>% # convert to date format using parse_date_time mutate(yr_mo_day = lubridate::parse_date_time(yr_day_mo, "ydm")) %>% # add month, day, & year columns and remove unneccesary date columns select(-mm_dd, -year, -yr_day_mo) %>% mutate(month = month(yr_mo_day, label = TRUE)) %>% mutate(day = day(yr_mo_day)) %>% mutate(year = year(yr_mo_day)) # ------------ # Timeseries plot # ------------ steel_timeseries <- steelhead_dates %>% # remove all observations with NA for date or value # note, value is the count of salmon that were recorded passing the damn drop_na(yr_mo_day, value) steel_gg <- ggplot(data = steel_timeseries, aes(x = yr_mo_day, y = value)) + geom_line() + theme_minimal() + labs(x = "Daily Dates", y = "Count of Steelhead Salmon", title = "Counts of Steelhead Salmon Passing Bonneville Dam (Daily records from 1940-2018)") + # center the title theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5)) steel_gg  There was a large spike in steelhead salmon counts in August 2009.  # ------------- # Season plot # ------------- steel_season <- steel_timeseries %>% # mutate(decade = round_date(year, unit = )) %>% group_by(year, month) %>% summarize(average_count = mean(value)) steel_season_gg <- ggplot(data = steel_season, aes(x = month, y = average_count, group = year)) + geom_line(aes(color = year)) + scale_color_paletteer_c("grDevices::SunsetDark") + theme_minimal() + labs(x = "Month", y = "Average count of Steelhead Salmon", title = "Steelhead Salmon Passing Bonneville Dam Average daily counts by month (1940-2019)") + # center the title theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5)) steel_season_gg  The largest amount of steelhead salmon pass through the Bonneville Dam in the summer months. The number of total salmon observed has increased overtime.  # ------------ # Annual steelhead passage counts # ------------ steel_annual <- steel_timeseries %>% group_by(year) %>% summarize(total_count = sum(value)) steel_annual_gg <- ggplot(data = steel_annual, aes(x = year, y = total_count)) + geom_line() + theme_minimal() + labs(x = "Year", y = "Annual count of Steelhead Salmon", title = "Counts of Steelhead Salmon Passing Bonneville Dam (Annual totals from 1940-2019)") + # center the title theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5)) steel_annual_gg  Steelhead Salmon counts increased dramatically starting in 1980 with peaks in 2001 and 2009 There has been an equally drastic drop in counts in the past decade
summary: Introduction This analysis looks at Steelhead salmon passage across the Bonneville Dam in Oregon from 1940 - 2019. The primary data collection is done byt the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers. The data includes counts of Steelhead Salmon recorded daily. There were days that did not include any salmon recordings and these data were removed from the analysis. Included in this analysis are a graph of daily recordings, a comparison of how seasonal recordings have changed over the years, and a graph of annual counts.
title: Steelhead salmon passage counts at Bonneville Dam
